title: Fourteen essential Back Bay restaurants - Restaurants
text:
Previous -- of -- Next The best way to eat at The Salty Pig? Grab a patio table, order up a charcuterie board, and wash it down with one of the many, many beers on tap. Address: 120 Darmouth St. The Boston Globe/Essdras M Suarezf Previous -- of -- Next Flour Bakery has four locations around the Boston area, but the Clarendon Street spot is the newest addition to its lineup. Go here to satisfy a serious craving for carbs, including fresh baguettes, gourmet sandwiches, layered cakes, rows of pastries, and more. Address: 131 Clarendon St. The Boston Globe/Wiqan Ang Previous -- of -- Next Tucked on Dartmouth between Boylston and Newbury, Lolita Cocina & Tequila Bar boasts a trendy nightclub vibe enhanced by dim lighting and plush couches. Expect a tequila list that’s 50+ deep, eclectic Mexican cuisine, and an arrangement of cotton candy topped with Pop Rocks. Address: 271 Darmouth St. The Boston Globe/Bill Greene Previous -- of -- Next Go to Asta for an impressive contemporary tasting menu. Their rotating prixe fixe selection provides three-, five-, and eight-course meals with wine pairings. Address: 47 Massachusetts Ave. The Boston Globe/Josh Reynolds Previous -- of -- Next Trident Booksellers & Cafe is a cozy bookstore with an extensive menu, but the all-day breakfast menu is the real star of the show. The apple and brie omelette and the lemon ricotta-stuffed French toast are musts. Address: 338 Newbury St. Trident Booksellers and Cafe/Katherine Kimball Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Enjoy modern Southern French cuisine at Bistro du Midi while overlooking the Public Garden. The restaurant has a classy upstairs, along with more casual seating downstairs at the bar or patio. Address: 272 Boylston St. The Boston Globe/Josh Reynolds Previous -- of -- Next Boylston Street’s Parish Cafe and Bar is known for a few things: The beer list that tops 100, the impressive sandwiches, and the outdoor seating. Plus, you can join the “Mug Club” by ordering all 125 beers within six months. Address: 361 Boylston St. The Boston Globe/Pat Greenhouse Previous -- of -- Next Casa Romero has an alley entryway and a subterranean vibe, giving the illusion you’re in a Mexican hacienda eating authentic Mexican cuisine. If you’re up for it, try their strong margaritas—we suggest the Margarita Picante if you like spice. Address: 30 Gloucester St. Casa Romero Previous -- of -- Next At Liquid Art House, a spacious restaurant/gallery hybrid, plates are as artistic as the rotating art exhibitions. It’s a kill-many-birds-with-one-stone kind of place, with art as decor and for sale, an ecclectic scene, and eye-popping food. Address: 100 Arlington St. The Boston Globe/Essdras M Suarez Previous -- of -- Next Sonsie is one of the city’s best spots for people-watching. Many of the tables face Newbury Street, and their floor-to-ceiling windows stay open during the warm months. Add that to a bottle of wine, and you have one entertaining afternoon. Address: 327 Newbury St. The Boston Globe/Wendy Maeda Previous -- of -- Next Advertisement Previous -- of -- Next Mistral’s elegant decor is reminiscent of southern France while accenting classic French cuisine with seasonal ingredients and spices. Spend an evening here if you’re looking to enjoy duck confit, prime sirloin carpaccio, or roasted hen. Address: 223 Columbus Ave. The Boston Globe/Josh Reynolds Previous -- of -- Next Piattini Wine Cafe is dedicated to serving small dishes of pasta, antipasti, bruschetta, and more. The idea is to order more than one piattini, which means ‘small plate’ in Italian, so you can peruse the selection. Address: 226 Newbury St. Piattini Wine Cafe/Josephine Megwa Previous -- of -- Next Unlike traditional oyster shacks, Select Oyster Bar explores coastal cuisines from locales like Cuba, Portugal, and Greece. The restaurant complements its dishes with a laid-back atmosphere, seating customers at a communal table, the bar, or private patio. Address: 50 Gloucester St. The Boston Globe/John Tlumacki Previous -- of -- Next Technically in Bay Village, this spot is so good we’ll let it slide. Mike & Patty’s is a hole-in-the-wall that attracts customers with its array of breakfast sandwiches. While a typical egg-and-cheese is available, go with the “Fancy”: two fried eggs, cheddar cheese, bacon, avocado, red onions, and mayo on toasted bread. Address: 12 Church St. Mike & Patty’s/Dan Watkins
